results.title: Easy does it
results.creator_credit: Anthony Gibb, Don Anderson, Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description:
This 1967 film is a light-hearted look at the correct methods of manual handling in order to avoid back strain and injury. The film shows footage of factory and manual labourers handling various heavy loads, including using equipment to aid safe lifting. This footage is interspersed with examples of everyday strain such as women hanging out the washing and lifting a baby from a pram; and moments of slapstick comedy as a man struggles to carry his bride over the threshold of their house and a man lifts a keg of beer at a barbeque.

Produced by Tasfilm Productions for the Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Robert Klippel
results.creator_credit: Keith Salvat, Keisal Films and Australia Council
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Painters, the sculptors: archival art series”.
Robert Klippel is viewed as one of Australia’s most important artists of the fifties and sixties. His humble beginnings (and obsession) with ship modelmaking was to influence and inform his work throughout his career as an artist. Klippel was a self-taught artist whose interest sprung from the processes he’d developed while model building, a scale which was to continue in his work throughout his career. Klippel had a strong preference for the solid built form of sculpture but found his work naturally becoming more linear in style. His developed language in the fifties and his need for intellectual peers saw him travel to Europe and New York to again resettle in Sydney, Australia where he developed strong artistic allies and his notoriety as an abstract expressionist artist along with Olsen and Passmore. This documentary charts Klippel’s role in a developing cultural nation.

results.title: Whole School Planning
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Institute of Educational Administration
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Case studies in effective schooling”.
Case studies in effective schooling presents first hand accounts of how individual schools have improved their effectiveness. The first episode, “Whole school planning” looks at planning as a manageable series of arrangements designed to involve all interested parties and to make the best use of limited resources. Deer Park Secondary College features in this case study.

results.title: Frontline
results.creator_credit: David Bradbury, Australian War Memorial, Tasmanian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, British Broadcasting Corporation and ABC
results.brief_description:
An account of the Vietnam War as seen through the camera of the late Australian war correspondent, Neil Davis. David Bradbury’s multi-award winning documentary also examines the ethical issues facing a man in the frontline who is not an active combatant.
Vietnam was a television war, a war said to have been lost in the lounge rooms of middle America, and not on the battlefield. This film explores the conflict, and Davis’ involvement in it, combining his original footage, comments and archival film. It includes the famous, historic footage of the fall of Saigon, which Davis was the only Western journalist to film.

Warning: some scenes may disturb.

results.title: Voices of Malaya
results.creator_credit: Terry Trench, Ralth Eaton, Colonial Office and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description: Voices of Malaya was made before hostilities in Malaya began, in the period immediately after World War 2. It is primarily a background study of the problems facing a country with a population of five million people - Malayan, Chinese-Malayan, Indian-Malayan and European - who are suffering from the aftermath of war. It shows the efforts of the mixed nationalities of Malaya working and living together in the best interests of their country. Music by Elizabeth Lutyens, played by The Philharmonic Orchestra and conducted by John Hollingsworth.

results.title: Royal visit to Melbourne 1963
results.creator_credit: H. Rodney Power, David Swift and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: Colour film record of the visit to Melbourne of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh. The three crowded, exciting days are show in detail. Includes the arrival of Her Majesty, presentation of the cup at the races at Flemington, a glittering State reception, service at Scot’s Church, Myer Music Bowl concert, Moomba parade, waving to country children en route to open the Royal Children’s Hospital, investiture at Government House, and farewell at the wharf.

results.title: The Challenge
results.creator_credit: Jack Rogers, Frank Killian and Ampol Petroleum Ltd
results.brief_description: This is a tribute to the Australians who sailed Gretel” in the America’s Cup…” Traces the construction of the Australian challenger, “Gretel”, its trials in America, and finally its efforts in the America’s Cup yacht races.
